  • ((He could hardly contain his fury.::
    他几乎克制不住自己的愤怒。))
  • ((She flew into a fury at the suggestion.::
    这个建议使她勃然大怒。))

gag

/ɡæɡ//ɡæɡ/
noun [C]
（使人无法说话或喊叫求助的）塞口布[英]^(a piece of cloth that is tied around a person's mouth or put inside it in order to stop the person from speaking, shouting, or calling for help)
  • ((Her hands and feet were tied and a gag placed over her mouth.::
    她的手脚被捆，嘴里被塞了一块布。))
（尤指喜剧演员的）插科打诨，笑话，玩笑[英]^(a joke or funny story, especially one told by a comedian (= person whose job is to make people laugh))
  • ((I did a few opening gags about the band that had played before me.::
    我拿表演上个节目的乐队说事，插科打诨说了几句开场白。))
US
恶作剧;滑稽动作;噱头[英]^(a trick played on someone or an action performed to entertain other people)
verb
-gg-
[I]
作呕[英]^(to experience the sudden uncomfortable feeling of tightness in the throat and stomach that makes you feel like you are going to vomit)
  • ((Just the smell of liver cooking makes me gag.::
    用动物肝脏做的菜我一闻就想吐。))
  • ((I tried my best to eat it but the meat was so fatty I gagged on it.::
    我尽最大的努力想吃了它，但肉太肥了，我还是想吐。))
[T]
塞住，捂住（某人的嘴）[英]^(to put a gag on someone's mouth)
  • ((He was bound and gagged and left in a cell for three days.::
    他被绑起来，嘴里塞了布，扔在一间小囚室中关了3天。))
[T often passive]
压制…的言论自由;限制…发言;使缄默[英]^(to prevent a person or organization from talking or writing about a particular subject)
  • ((The media has obviously been gagged because nothing has been reported.::
    显然媒体已被封了口，因为什么都没有报道。))

be gagging for/to do something

/ɡæɡ//ɡæɡ/
verb
-gg-
UK
我真想喝一品脱冰啤酒。[英]^(to be very eager to do something)
  • ((I was gagging for a pint of cold lager.::
    我真想喝一品脱冰啤酒。))

be gagging for it

/ɡæɡ//ɡæɡ/
verb
-gg-
UK
to be very eager to have sex
  • You wait - he'll be gagging for it!

gala

/ˈɡɑː.lə//ˈɡeɪ.lə/
noun [C]
（通常指包括很多表演节目的）庆典，盛会，演出[英]^(a special public occasion at which there is a lot of entertainment, usually in the form of different types of performances)
  • ((There will be many stars performing in the Royal Ballet's Gala Night, held in aid of children's charities.::
    为资助儿童慈善机构而进行的皇家芭蕾舞剧团演出之夜将有众多明星加盟献艺。))
UK
运动会，体育竞赛（尤指游泳）[英]^(a sports competition, especially in swimming)
  • ((a swimming gala::
    游泳比赛))

Gala

/ˈɡɑː.lə//ˈɡeɪ.lə/
noun [C]
(also Gala apple)
佳丽苹果[英]^(an apple with a reddish skin and a sweet taste, that can be eaten uncooked or cooked)
  • ((There is nothing like sinking your teeth into a sweet, crunchy Gala.::
    没有什么比咀嚼甜美、松脆的佳丽苹果更美妙的了。))
  • ((The Gala apple was first found in 1939 in New Zealand.::
    佳丽苹果于1939年首次在新西兰被发现。))

gall

/ɡɔːl//ɡɑːl/
noun [U]
鲁莽;厚颜无耻[英]^(rudeness and the quality of being unable to understand that your behaviour or what you say is not acceptable to other people)
  • ((Considering that he never even bothers to visit my parents, I'm amazed that Tim has the gall to ask them for money!::
    蒂姆从不去看望我父母，可他竟然有脸去向他们要钱，真让我吃惊！))
verb [T]
使恼怒，激怒[英]^(to make someone feel annoyed)
  • ((I think it galls him to take orders from a younger and less experienced colleague.::
    我想，要他去听命于一个比他年轻且资历比他浅的同事，他会很恼火。))

gallop

/ˈɡæl.əp//ˈɡæl.əp/
verb
[I or T]
（马）飞跑，疾驰;（人）骑马奔驰[英]^((of a horse) to run fast so that all four feet come off the ground together in each act of forward movement, or (of a person) to ride a horse that is running in this way)
  • ((We galloped through the woods.::
    我们骑马从林中飞驰而过。))
[I usually + adv/prep]
急速移动;快速行动[英]^(to move or act quickly)
  • ((It is the height of folly and a tragic waste to gallop into war.::
    仓促发动战争是极其愚蠢的行为，是一种可悲的浪费。))
noun [S]
（马）奔驰[英]^(the fast run or speed of a horse when it is galloping, or an act of galloping)
  • ((At the sound of gunfire the horse suddenly broke into a gallop.::
    枪声一响，那匹马突然飞奔起来。))
高速度[英]^(a fast speed)
  • ((We had to complete the work at a gallop (= very quickly).::
    我们不得不快马加鞭将工作赶完。))

gape

/ɡeɪp//ɡeɪp/
verb [I]
目瞪口呆地看，瞠目结舌地注视[英]^(to look in great surprise at someone or something, especially with an open mouth)
  • ((They stood gaping at the pig in the kitchen.::
    他们站在那里目瞪口呆地看着厨房里的那头猪。))
张开;裂开[英]^(to be or become wide open)
  • ((Peter's jacket gaped at the seams.::
    彼得的夹克衫开了线，裂了一个口子。))

garnish

/ˈɡɑː.nɪʃ//ˈɡɑːr.nɪʃ/
verb [T]
在（食物）上加饰菜，（用菜）为（食物）加装饰[英]^(to decorate food with a small amount of different food)
  • ((Garnish the dish with parsley before serving.::
    这道菜端上桌之前，上面配些欧芹点缀一下。))
noun [C or U]
在（食物）上加饰菜，（用菜）为（食物）加装饰[英]^(a small amount of different food used to decorate a dish or serving of food)
  • ((a lemon and herb garnish::
    用柠檬和香草做的饰菜))

garrison

noun [C, + sing/pl verb]
/ˈɡær.ɪ.sən//ˈɡer.ə.sən/
卫戍部队，守备部队;卫戍区，驻防地[英]^(a group of soldiers living in or defending a town or building, or the buildings that the soldiers live in)
  • ((The 100-strong garrison had received no supplies for a week.::
    这支100人的守备部队已经一个星期没有得到补给了。))
  • ((a garrison town::
    有驻防的城市))
verb [T usually passive + adv/prep]
/ˈɡær.ɪ.sən//ˈɡer.ɪ.sən/
派（兵）驻防[英]^(to put a group of soldiers in a place in order to live there and defend it)
  • ((Troops are garrisoned in the area.::
    部队在这个地区驻防。))

gel

noun [U]
/dʒel//dʒel/
（尤指用于洗发或护肤的）凝胶，冻胶[英]^(a thick, clear, liquid substance, especially one used on the hair or body)
  • ((shower gel::
    沐浴凝胶))
  • ((hair gel::
    发胶))
verb
/dʒel//dʒel/
-ll-
[I]
(US also jell)
形成胶体;胶化;胶凝[英]^(to change from a liquid into a thick, soft solid)
[I]
(US also jell)
（想法或局势）变得更清楚，显得更明确[英]^(If an idea or situation gels, it starts to become more clear and fixed.)
  • ((They talked a lot about opening a restaurant, but their plans never gelled.::
    他们总是说要开一个餐馆，可是从来没有付诸实践过。))
[I]
(US also jell)
形成亲密关系;结成好友[英]^(If two or more people gel, they form a good relationship or become friends.)
  • ((The team really gelled during the first few games of the season.::
    在这个赛季头几场比赛中，球队表现得很有凝聚力，配合十分默契。))
[T]
上发胶[英]^(to put gel on your hair)
  • ((He had spiky, light brown hair, shaved at the sides and gelled on top.::
    他浅褐色的头发一簇簇地直立着，剃去两鬓，头顶上打了发胶。))

gem

/dʒem//dʒem/
noun [C]
(also gemstone)
（尤指切割成规则形状的）宝石[英]^(a jewel (= precious stone), especially when cut into a particular regular shape)
难能可贵的人（或物）;被人喜爱的人（或物）;非常有用的人（或物）[英]^(someone or something that is very good, pleasing, or useful)
  • ((He's a real gem - you'd be a fool to break up with him.::
    他可真是个宝贝——你得是个傻瓜才会想要跟他分手。))
  • ((The coffee house is a hidden gem (= something that not a lot of people know about).::
    这个咖啡馆真是块隐藏的瑰宝。))

general

/ˈdʒen.ər.əl//ˈdʒen.ər.əl/
adjective
B2
全体的，总的，普遍的[英]^(involving or relating to most or all people, things, or places, especially when these are considered as a unit)
  • ((The general feeling is that justice was not served.::
    普遍的看法是这样做没有达成公平合理。))
  • ((There is general concern about rising crime rates.::
    人们普遍对犯罪率上升感到担忧。))
  • ((My general impression of the place was good.::
    我对这个地方总的印象很好。))
  • ((The talk is intended to be of general interest (= of interest to most people).::
    这次商谈是要探讨大家普遍感兴趣的话题。))
  • ((Rain will become more general in the southeast during the afternoon.::
    降雨范围将在下午进一步扩展到东南地区。))
B1
大体的；大致的；笼统的[英]^(not detailed, but including the most basic or necessary information)
  • ((What he said was very general.::
    他说得很笼统。))
  • ((The school aims to give children a general background in a variety of subjects.::
    学校旨在向孩子们概要介绍各种学科的背景知识。))
  • ((I'm not an expert, so I can only speak in general terms on this matter.::
    我不是专家，我只能泛泛地谈这个问题。))
B2
一般性的；普通的；非专门的[英]^(including a lot of things or subjects and not limited to only one or a few)
  • ((general knowledge::
    常识))
（用于头衔中，表示负责整个组织或公司）总管的，首席的，全面负责的[英]^(used as part of the title of a job of someone who is in charge of a whole organization or company)
  • ((the general manager::
    总经理))
  • ((the General Secretary of the UN::
    联合国秘书长))
noun [C]
(also General)
（尤指陆军中的）将军[英]^(an officer of very high rank, especially in the army)
  • ((He was promoted to the rank of general.::
    他被晋升为将军。))
  • ((General Brown/Roger Brown::
    布朗将军／罗杰·布朗将军))
  • ((Thank you, General.::
    谢谢，将军。))

in general

/ˈdʒen.ər.əl//ˈdʒen.ər.əl/
adjective
B1
(also as a general rule)
一般来说，男人个子比女人高。[英]^(usually, or in most situations)
  • ((In general, men are taller than women.::
    一般来说，男人个子比女人高。))
B2
那么，除了踝部的伤病，你身体总的来说怎么样？[英]^(considering the whole of someone or something, and not just a particular part of him, her, or it)
  • ((So, apart from the bad ankle, how are you in general?::
    那么，除了踝部的伤病，你身体总的来说怎么样？))

be in the general interest

/ˈdʒen.ər.əl//ˈdʒen.ər.əl/
adjective
政府只能说，透露更多的信息有损公众的利益。[英]^(to be a good thing for the public)
  • ((The government will only say it is not in the general interest to reveal any more information.::
    政府只能说，透露更多的信息有损公众的利益。))

the general

/ˈdʒen.ər.əl//ˈdʒen.ər.əl/
adjective
一般事物；大致情况，总体情况[英]^(things considered as a unit and without giving attention to details)
  • ((His book moves from the general to the particular.::
    他的书先介绍总体情况然后探讨具体问题。))

genesis

/ˈdʒen.ə.sɪs//ˈdʒen.ə.sɪs/
noun [S]
（事物的）形成，发生，起源，创始[英]^(the origin of something, when it is begun or starts to exist)
  • ((The story had its genesis in a conversation the author had with his mother.::
    故事以作者与母亲的一段对话开始。))
  • ((research into the genesis of cancer::
    对癌症病因的研究))

the gentry

gig

/ɡɪɡ//ɡɪɡ/
noun [C]
（尤指演奏现代或流行乐的）演奏会[英]^(a single performance by a musician or group of musicians, especially playing modern or pop music, or by a comedian (= a performer who makes people laugh, for example by telling jokes or funny stories))
  • ((The band is going to Atlanta to play a gig at the Fox Theatre.::
    乐队将到亚特兰大的福克斯剧场演出。))
  • The comedian did her first gig at the Comedy Store in London.
（尤指旧时的）双轮小马车[英]^(a light two-wheeled carriage pulled by one horse, used especially in the past)
  • He had the horse and gig brought to the door.
千兆字节，吉字节（同 gigabyte）[英]^(a gigabyte)
  • I don't get why people want to buy something that only has 14.5 gigs of useable memory.
verb [I]
-gg-
做乐师[英]^((of a musician or group of musicians) to perform gigs)
  • ((She gigged at bars for years before becoming famous.::
    她出名前在酒吧里做了好几年乐师。))

  • ((a bottle of gin::

  • ((ground (= powdered) ginger::

  • ((crystallized ginger::
    蜜饯生姜))

[S] UK
长着姜黄色头发的人[英]^(a person who has red or orange-brown hair)
  • ((Hey, ginger, what are you doing?::
    哎，黄毛，你在干什么？))

  • ((rum and ginger::

    他的外号叫生姜，因为他的头发是姜黄色的。))

  • ((The glands in my neck are a little bit swollen.::

glaze

/ɡleɪz//ɡleɪz/
verb
[T]
给…上釉;给…上光;使光滑，使光亮[英]^(to make a surface shiny by putting a liquid substance onto it and leaving it or heating it until it dries)
  • ((Glaze the pastry with beaten egg.::
    往油酥面团里和入打匀的鸡蛋，使其滑亮。))
  • ((The pot had been badly glazed.::
    这个罐子上釉上得很差。))
[I]
(also glaze over)
（眼神）变呆滞，发呆[英]^(If your eyes glaze or glaze over, they stay still and stop showing any emotion because you are bored or tired or have stopped listening.)
  • ((Among the audience, eyes glazed over and a few heads started to nod.::
    听众目光变得呆滞无神，一些人则开始打盹。))
[T]
给（窗户）装玻璃[英]^(to put a piece of glass into a window or the windows of a building)
  • ((The house is nearly finished but it hasn't been glazed yet.::
    房子即将完工，但是窗户还没有装玻璃。))
noun [C]
釉，釉料;（用来使食物有光泽的）浆，汁[英]^(a substance used to glaze something)
  • ((a cake with a dark chocolate glaze::
    浇有黑巧克力的蛋糕))
  • ((pottery with a fine, translucent glaze::
    发半透明光泽的陶器))

gleam

/ɡliːm//ɡliːm/
verb [I]
发微光;闪烁;闪现[英]^(to produce or reflect a small, bright light)
  • ((He polished the table until it gleamed.::
    他把桌子擦得锃光瓦亮。))
（眼睛）闪烁[英]^(When eyes gleam, they shine in a way that expresses a particular emotion.)
  • ((His eyes gleamed with/in triumph.::
    他眼中闪现出胜利的光芒。))
noun [C usually singular]
闪烁;闪亮;闪现[英]^(an occasion when something gleams)

glint

/ɡlɪnt//ɡlɪnt/
verb [I]
（由于表面反射而）闪烁，闪光[英]^(to produce small, bright flashes of light reflected from a surface)
  • ((The stream glinted in the moonlight.::
    月光下溪流闪着粼粼波光。))
  • ((A large diamond glinted on her finger.::
    她手指上一颗硕大的钻戒闪闪发光。))
（眼睛）闪闪发光[英]^(When someone's eyes glint, they look bright, expressing a strong emotion.)
  • ((She smiled at him, her eyes glinting with mischief.::
    她向他微笑着，眼神里透着调皮。))
noun [C usually singular]
闪烁，闪光[英]^(an occasion when something glints)
  • ((the glint of a knife::
    刀子的闪光))
  • ((a mischievous glint in his eye::
    他眼中闪烁的调皮的光芒))

glisten

/ˈɡlɪs.ən//ˈɡlɪs.ən/
verb [I]
（因潮湿、油亮或光滑的表面反光而）闪光，闪耀，闪亮[英]^(to shine by reflecting light from a wet or smooth surface)
  • ((The grass glistened in the early-morning dew.::
    清晨，小草顶着露珠晶莹发亮。))
  • ((His eyes glistened with tears.::
    他的眼里闪着晶莹的泪花。))

gloss

/ɡlɒs//ɡlɑːs/
noun
[S or U]
光亮，光泽[英]^(a smooth, shiny appearance on the surface of something)
  • ((Marble can be polished to a high gloss.::
    大理石可以被磨得非常光滑。))
  • ((This varnish provides a long-lasting and hard-wearing gloss finish.::
    用这种清漆做亮光漆可以使表面光亮、持久、耐磨。))
[U]
高光漆，亮光漆[英]^(paint that produces a smooth, shiny appearance on a surface)
  • ((We'll need a litre of gloss (paint) to cover the woodwork.::
    我们需要一升亮光漆来漆一下木建部分。))
  • ((All the shades are available in matt or gloss.::
    所有颜色都有亮光和亚光两种。))
[U]
一种使（嘴唇、头发、皮肤等）显得光亮的物质[英]^(a substance used to make your lips, hair, or skin appear shiny)
  • ((lip gloss::
    唇蜜))
[C]
注释；评注[英]^(an explanation for a word or phrase)
  • ((Difficult expressions are explained in the glosses at the bottom of the page.::
    难以理解的词组在页脚都有注释。))
verb [T]
给…加注释（或注解）[英]^(to provide an explanation for a word or phrase)
  • ((In the school edition of the book, the older and more rare words have been glossed.::
    这本书的教学用版本对一些较古老和较生僻的词作了注释。))

glossy

/ˈɡlɒs.i//ˈɡlɑː.si/
adjective
平滑有光泽的[英]^(smooth and shiny)
  • ((She has wonderfully glossy hair.::
    她有一头顺滑的秀发。))
  • ((a dog with a glossy coat::
    亮毛狗))
（书、杂志）用高级亮光纸印刷的[英]^(A glossy book or magazine has been produced on shiny and expensive paper and contains many colour pictures.)
  • ((a glossy coffee-table book::
    用亮光纸印刷的精装大开本画册))
  • ((a pile of glossy magazines/car brochures::
    一摞用高级亮光纸印刷的杂志／汽车广告册))
空有其表的[英]^(looking attractive, but often not having serious value or quality)
  • ((This magazine is full of glossy advertisements for aftershave.::
    这本杂志满是介绍须后水的广告，尽是些夸夸其谈的东西。))
noun [C]
（同 glossy magazine）[英]^(a glossy magazine)
US
用亮光纸打印的照片[英]^(a photograph printed on smooth shiny paper)

gospel

/ˈɡɒs.pəl//ˈɡɑː.spəl/
noun
[C]
福音书（《圣经》中记载耶稣生平的四福音书之一）[英]^(any of the four books of the Bible that contain details of the life of Jesus Christ)
  • ((St Mark's Gospel/the Gospel according to St Mark::
    《马可福音》))
[U]
(also gospel truth)
（用于强调某事的真实性）绝对真实[英]^(the complete truth)
  • ((If Mary tells you something, you can take it as gospel.::
    玛丽告诉你的事，你可以绝对相信。))
[U]
(also gospel music)
（起源于美国黑人中的）福音音乐[英]^(a style of religious music originally performed by black Americans)
[S]
（个人的）信条，信念[英]^(a set of principles or ideas that someone believes in)
  • ((the gospel of hard work::
    勤奋工作的信条))

the gospel

/ˈɡɒs.pəl//ˈɡɑː.spəl/

福音（指耶稣的教诲）[英]^(the teachings of Jesus Christ)
  • ((to preach/spread the gospel::

Gothic

/ˈɡɒθ.ɪk//ˈɡɑː.θɪk/
adjective
哥特式的，哥特风格的（12到16世纪流行于欧洲的建筑风格，有尖拱、尖窗、很高的天花板以及细长的柱子）[英]^(of or like a style of building that was common in Europe between the 12th and 16th centuries and whose characteristics are pointed arches and windows, high ceilings, and tall, thin columns)
  • ((a Gothic cathedral::
    哥特式大教堂))
  • ((Gothic arches::
    哥特式拱门))
（文学、电影等）哥特派的，哥特风格的（描述在恐怖的地方发生的怪异故事）[英]^(used to describe writing or films in which strange things happen in frightening places)

graft

/ɡrɑːft//ɡræft/
noun
[C]
移植的皮肤（或骨骼）;嫁接用的枝条（或芽）[英]^(a piece of healthy skin or bone cut from one part of a person's body and used to repair another damaged part, or a piece cut from one living plant and attached to another plant so that it grows there)
  • ((He has had a skin graft on his badly burned arm.::
    他的胳膊严重烧伤，已经进行了植皮手术。))
[U] UK
工作[英]^(work)
  • ((I've never been afraid of hard graft.::
    我从来就不怕做繁重的工作。))
[U] US
（滥用政治权力进行的）贪污，受贿，以权谋私[英]^(the act of getting money or advantage through the dishonest use of political power and influence)
  • ((The whole government was riddled with graft, bribery, and corruption.::
    政府内到处充斥着以权谋私、行贿受贿和贪污腐败行为。))
verb
[T]
移植（皮肤、骨等）;嫁接[英]^(to take and put in place a graft)
  • ((Skin was removed from her leg and grafted on/onto her face.::
    从她的腿上取下皮肤移植到了她的脸上。))
[T]
使紧密结合；将（新的事物）移植于[英]^(to join or add something new)
  • ((The management tried unsuccessfully to graft new working methods onto the existing ways of doing things.::
    管理层试图将新的工作方法和现有的经营方式相结合，但是并未成功。))
[I] UK
努力工作[英]^(to work hard)
  • ((It was very sad that after spending all those years grafting (away), he died so soon after he retired.::
    他拼命工作了那么多年，可刚退休就去世了，真是让人伤感。))

granite

/ˈɡræn.ɪt//ˈɡræn.ɪt/
noun [U]
花岗岩，花岗石[英]^(a very hard, grey, pink, or black rock, used for building)

grate

/ɡreɪt//ɡreɪt/
verb
[T]
磨碎，擦碎（食物）[英]^(to rub food against a grater in order to cut it into a lot of small pieces)
  • ((grated cheese::
    磨碎的奶酪))
[I]
摩擦；发出刺耳的摩擦声[英]^(When two hard objects grate, they rub together, sometimes making a sharp unpleasant sound.)
[I]
使烦恼，使烦躁，使难受[英]^(When a noise or behaviour grates, it annoys you.)
  • ((After a while her voice really started to grate on me.::
    过了一会儿，她的聒噪声的确开始让我心烦了。))
  • ((It's the way she's always talking about herself - it just grates on me.::
    她总是喋喋不休地说她自己的事情——简直烦死我了。))
noun [C]
（壁炉上的）金属炉架，炉箅[英]^(a metal structure that holds coal or wood in a fireplace)

gratify

/ˈɡræt.ɪ.faɪ//ˈɡræt̬.ə.faɪ/
verb [T]
使高兴;使满意;满足（某人的愿望、需求等）[英]^(to please someone, or to satisfy a wish or need)
  • ((We were gratified by the response to our appeal.::
    呼吁得到积极响应，我们感到非常欣慰。))
  • ((He was gratified to see how well his students had done.::
    看到学生们成绩如此出众，他非常高兴。))

gravel

/ˈɡræv.əl//ˈɡræv.əl/
noun [U]
沙砾，砾石[英]^(small, rounded stones, often mixed with sand)
  • ((a gravel path::
    石子路))

greed

/ɡriːd//ɡriːd/
noun [U]
C1
（尤指对食物或钱财的）贪婪，贪心，贪欲[英]^(a very strong wish to continuously get more of something, especially food or money)
  • ((I don't know why I'm eating more - it's not hunger, it's just greed!::
    我不知道自己为什么还想吃——不是因为觉得饿，只是贪嘴！))
  • ((He was unsympathetic with many house sellers, complaining that they were motivated by greed.::
    他对很多卖房者表示反感，抱怨说他们是受贪念驱使。))

grid

/ɡrɪd//ɡrɪd/
noun [C]
网格，方格;格栅，格子[英]^(a pattern or structure made from horizontal and vertical lines crossing each other to form squares)
  • ((A metal grid had been placed over the hole to prevent people from falling in.::
    在洞口铺了一个铁格栅，以免有人跌入。))
  • ((In Barcelona the streets are laid out in/on a grid system.::
    巴塞罗那的街道是棋盘式的布局。))
电力网，输电网[英]^(a system of wires through which electricity is connected to different power stations across a region)
  • ((the national grid::
    全国输电网))
（地图的）坐标方格[英]^(a pattern of squares with numbers or letters used to find places on a map)
(also starting grid)
赛车起跑线[英]^(a pattern of lines marking the start of the track in motor racing (= a sport of racing very fast and powerful cars around a track))
  • ((In all, 26 drivers will be on the starting grid tomorrow.::
    明天总共有 26 名车手将在起跑线上。))

grievance

/ˈɡriː.vəns//ˈɡriː.vəns/
noun [C or U]
不平，委屈;不满，抱怨，牢骚[英]^(a complaint or a strong feeling that you have been treated unfairly)
  • ((A special committee has been appointed to handle prisoners' grievances.::
    已经指派一个特别委员会去处理犯人的不满情绪。))
  • ((Bill still harbours/nurses a grievance against his employers for not promoting him.::
    因为没有得到提升，比尔对他的雇主仍然心怀不满。))
  • ((The small amount of compensation is a source of grievance to the people forced to leave their homes.::
    被迫离开家园的人们仅获得很少的补偿，这成为激起他们不满的一个诱因。))

grimace

/ˈɡrɪm.əs//ˈɡrɪm.əs/
verb [I]
（因疼痛或厌恶而）做鬼脸，做怪相[英]^(to make an expression of pain, strong dislike, etc. in which the face twists in an ugly way)
  • ((He tried to stand and grimaced with pain.::
    他试图站起来，结果疼得龇牙咧嘴。))

grit

noun [U]
/ɡrɪt//ɡrɪt/
砂，沙砾，沙粒[英]^(very small pieces of stone or sand)
  • ((The road had been covered with grit.::
    以前这条路一直铺满沙砾。))
勇气，毅力[英]^(courage and determination despite difficulty)
  • ((It takes true (= real) grit to stand up to a bully.::
    面对一个恃强凌弱者奋起反抗确实需要勇气。))
verb [T]
/ɡrɪt//ɡrɪt/
-tt-
UK
（为防滑）在（路面上）撒沙砾[英]^(to put small stones on a road or path that is covered in ice, in order to make it safer)
  • ((Council lorries had been out gritting the icy roads the night before.::
    政务委员会在头天夜里派出卡车在结冰的路面上撒了沙砾。))

  • Do you eat your grits with syrup, or just plain?

/ɡruːm/ɡrʊm//ɡruːm/ɡrʊm/
verb [T]

  • ((Polly spends hours in the stables grooming her pony.::
    波莉在马厩里刷洗她的小马，一干就是几个小时。))

  • ((She was being groomed for leadership.::
    她正在接受培训以担任领导。))
  • ((My boss is grooming me to take over his job next year.::
    我的老板正在栽培我，以便下一年我可以接替他。))
（尤指通过互联网）勾引，诱骗，诱奸（儿童）[英]^(to become friends with a child with the intention of trying to persuade the child to have a sexual relationship)
noun [C]
B1
（同 bridegroom）[英]^(a bridegroom)
  • ((The bride and groom walked down the aisle together.::
    新娘和新郎一起走过教堂的过道。))
马夫[英]^(a person whose job is to take care of and clean horses)

groove

/ɡruːv//ɡruːv/
noun [C]
沟;槽;辙;纹[英]^(a long, narrow, hollow space cut into a surface)
  • ((The window slides along a deep metal groove to open and close.::
    窗户沿着一条深深的金属槽滑动打开或关上。))
MEDICAL

  • ((There may be nerve compression at the elbow in the ulnar groove.::
    在手肘处的尺神经沟处可能发生了神经压迫。))

growl

/ɡraʊl//ɡraʊl/
verb [I]
（通常指因为愤怒）发出低沉的吼叫，咆哮[英]^(to make a low, rough sound, usually in anger)
  • ((The dog growled at her and snapped at her ankles.::
    那条狗咆哮着在她脚踝上咬了一口。))
  • (("Not now, I'm busy," he growled.::
    “现在不行，我忙着呢，”他吼道。))

grudge

/ɡrʌdʒ//ɡrʌdʒ/
noun [C]
怨恨，嫌隙，积怨[英]^(a strong feeling of anger and dislike for a person who you feel has treated you badly, especially one that lasts for a long time)
  • ((I don't bear any grudge against you.::
    我对你没有丝毫怨恨。))
  • ((Amanda still has/holds a grudge against me for refusing to lend her that money.::
    阿曼达到现在仍对我不借钱给她一事耿耿于怀。))
verb [T]
(also begrudge)
吝惜;勉强地做，勉强地给[英]^(to not want to spend time or money on someone or something, or to not want to give something to someone)
  • ((She grudged every hour she spent helping him.::
    她很不情愿花时间帮他。))
认为…不应得到；忌妒[英]^(to think that someone does not deserve something good that they have)
  • ((I don't grudge you your holiday, it's just that you've chosen a bad time to go.::
    我不是认为你不该去度假，只是觉得你选的时机不合适。))

grumble

/ˈɡrʌm.bəl//ˈɡrʌm.bəl/
verb [I]
发牢骚，抱怨，嘟囔[英]^(to complain about someone or something in an annoyed way)
  • ((She spent the evening grumbling to me about her job.::
    她一晚上都在向我抱怨她的工作。))
  • (("You never hang your coat up," she grumbled.::
    “你就从来不会把外套挂起来。”她埋怨道。))
（通常因为饿而）肚子咕咕叫[英]^(If your stomach grumbles, it makes a low, continuous noise, usually because you are hungry.)
noun [C usually plural]
（同 complaint）[英]^(a complaint)
  • ((When the teacher assigned extra homework, she heard a few grumbles from the kids.::
    要是再让我听到你抱怨饭不好吃，你就自己做！))

grunt

/ɡrʌnt//ɡrʌnt/
verb [I]
（猪）发出呼噜声[英]^((of a pig) to make a low, rough noise)
  • ((The pigs were grunting contentedly as they ate their food.::
    猪边吃边发出满意的哼哼声。))
（人通常因为愤怒或疼痛而）发出哼声，嘟囔着说，咕哝[英]^((of a person) to make a short, low sound instead of speaking, usually because of anger or pain)
  • ((He hauled himself over the wall, grunting with the effort.::
    他费力地翻过墙，累得直哼哼。))
  • (("Too tired," he grunted and sat down.::
    “累死了，”他呻吟着坐下来。))

guerrilla

/ɡəˈrɪl.ə//ɡəˈrɪl.ə/
noun [C]
(also guerilla)
游击队员[英]^(a member of an unofficial military group that is trying to change the government by making sudden, unexpected attacks on the official army forces)
  • ((A small band of guerrillas has blown up a train in the mountains.::
    一小队游击队员炸毁了山区的一列火车。))
  • ((guerrilla warfare::
    游击战))
adjective [before noun]
出奇制胜的，用奇招的[英]^(using unusual methods to create or get attention for your ideas, art, products, etc., usually ones that cost little money and involve using public spaces)
  • He films on the streets, with a tiny budget - this is guerrilla film-making.
  • A new work by the "guerrilla" artist known as Banksy has appeared.

gulp

/ɡʌlp//ɡʌlp/
verb
[I or T]
大口地吃（或喝）;（因为害怕、吃惊、激动等）倒吸气，喘不过气来[英]^(to eat or drink food or liquid quickly by swallowing it in large amounts, or to make a swallowing movement because of fear, surprise, or excitement)
  • ((She gulped down her drink and made a hasty exit.::
    她大口喝下饮料后急匆匆地出去了。))
  • ((When it was his turn to dive, he gulped and stepped up onto the diving board.::
    轮到他跳水时，他深吸了一口气后走上跳板。))
[T]
大口大口地吸（气）[英]^(to breathe in a large amount of air very quickly)
noun [C]
吞，咽[英]^(an act of gulping)
  • ((He swallowed his drink in one gulp.::
    他把杯中的酒一饮而尽。))
  • ((She rose to the surface of the water once every minute to get/take a gulp of air.::
    她每隔一分钟要把头探出水面吸一大口气。))

gutter

/ˈɡʌt.ər//ˈɡʌt̬.ɚ/
noun [C]

（屋檐的）雨水槽，檐槽，天沟[英]^(an open pipe, usually at the lower edge of a roof, that collects and carries away rain)
verb [I]
（火焰或蜡烛，尤指在熄灭前）忽明忽暗，摇曳不定[英]^((of a flame or candle) to burn unevenly and weakly, especially before completely stopping burning)
  • ((a guttering candle::
    摇曳不定的烛光))

the gutter

/ˈɡʌt.ər//ˈɡʌt̬.ɚ/

    她出生在一个极度贫困的家庭，但是她从社会最底层奋力挣扎出来，成功地拥有了自己的公司。))

    在过去的6个月里，他们的利润减少了一半。))

/hɪˈɡem.ə.ni/hɪˈdʒem.ə.ni/ˈheɡ.ɪ.mə.ni/ˈhedʒ.ɪ.mə.ni//hɪˈdʒem.ə.ni/ˈhedʒ.ə.moʊ.ni/

/ˈhaɪ.lənd//ˈhaɪ.lənd/

    高地泉水))

  • ((The groom wore Highland dress tartan.::
    新郎穿着苏格兰高地格呢短裙。))

Highland

/ˈhaɪ.lənd//ˈhaɪ.lənd/
noun
海兰，高地（位于苏格兰北部，原为苏格兰九个地方行政区之一，1996年撤销，现为一个议会区）[英]^(an area in the north of Scotland that was one of nine local government regions until 1996 and is now a council area (= an area with its own local government))
  • ((In Highland, some 83% of the funding of the council is from the Scottish Executive.::
    高地议会区83% 的经费来自苏格兰行政院。))
  • ((Officials from the Highland Council have been working closely with local communities.::
    高地议会区的官员与当地社区的合作一向非常紧密。))

hiss

/hɪs//hɪs/
verb
[I]
发嘶嘶声;发嘘声[英]^(to make a noise like a long s sound)
  • ((Why do snakes hiss?::
    蛇为什么发出嘶嘶声？))
  • ((The iron was hissing and spluttering.::
    铁块发出嘶嘶声并且火花四溅。))
  • ((People in the audience were hissing their disapproval.::
    观众们发出嘘声表示不满。))
[T]
悄声且生气地说[英]^(to say something in a quiet angry way)
  • (("Shut up, Tom!" she hissed.::
    “闭嘴，汤姆！”她生气地小声说道。))
noun [C or U]
嘶嘶声;嘘声[英]^(a sound like the letter s)
  • ((I heard a hiss and a pop as the cork came out of the bottle.::
    我先听到了嘶嘶声，然后是砰的一声，瓶塞就弹出了瓶子。))

hitch

/hɪtʃ//hɪtʃ/
noun [C]
临时故障，小问题[英]^(a temporary difficulty that causes a short delay)
  • ((Due to a slight technical hitch the concert will be starting half an hour late.::
    由于出了一点小小的技术故障，音乐会将推后半小时开始。))
  • The ceremony went off without a hitch.
verb [T usually + adv/prep]
（用绳子）系住；（用钩子）挂住[英]^(to fasten something to another thing by tying it with a rope or using a metal hook)
  • ((The horses were hitched to a shiny, black carriage.::
    马匹被套在一辆黑亮的大车上。))
  • ((We just need to hitch the trailer (on)to the car and then we can go.::
    我们只需把拖车挂在汽车后面，这样就可以走了。))

hitch a lift/ride

/hɪtʃ//hɪtʃ/
verb
他们搭乘一辆过路的车到了爱丁堡。[英]^(to get a free ride in someone else's vehicle as a way of travelling)
  • ((They hitched a lift to Edinburgh from a passing car.::
    他们搭乘一辆过路的车到了爱丁堡。))

holistic

/həˈlɪs.tɪk//hoʊlˈɪs.tɪk/
adjective
整体的，全面的[英]^(dealing with or treating the whole of something or someone and not just a part)
  • ((My doctor takes a holistic approach to disease.::
    我的医生采用了一种全面的治疗方法。))
  • ((Ecological problems usually require holistic solutions.::
    生态问题通常需要全面的解决方法。))

holly

/ˈhɒl.i//ˈhɑː.li/
noun [C or U]
冬青[英]^(a small evergreen tree (= one that never loses its leaves) with shiny, sharp leaves and small, round, red fruit. Holly is often used as a Christmas decoration in Europe and North America.)

homicide

/ˈhɒm.ɪ.saɪd//ˈhɑː.mə.saɪd/
noun [C or U]
LAW • US
谋杀（行为）[英]^((an act of) murder)
  • ((He was convicted of homicide.::
    他被判犯有谋杀罪。))
  • ((The number of homicides in the city has risen sharply.::
    这个城市的杀人案急剧增多。))

homosexual

/ˌhəʊ.məˈsek.ʃu.əl//ˌhoʊ.moʊˈsek.ʃu.əl/
noun [C]
（尤指男性）同性恋者[英]^(used to describe a man who is sexually or romantically attracted to men, or a woman who is sexually or romantically attracted to women)
  • During that period in American history, men who were thought to be Communists or homosexuals were routinely interrogated and sometimes imprisoned.

hood

/hʊd//hʊd/
noun [C]
B2
（衣服上的）兜帽，风帽[英]^(part of a piece of clothing that can be pulled up to cover the top and back of the head)
  • ((The coat has a detachable hood.::
    这件大衣有可拆卸的风帽。))
（为了挡住视线或不让人认出而戴的）头套，头罩[英]^(a bag that is put over someone's head so that they cannot see or be recognized)
  • ((The prisoners had been tortured and made to wear hoods.::
    囚犯们遭到了拷打并被强行戴上了头罩。))
篷，罩[英]^(a part that covers or shelters a piece of equipment)
  • ((The hood over the air vent is loose.::
    排气口的罩子松了。))
US
(UK bonnet)
（汽车的）引擎罩，发动机盖[英]^(the metal cover over the part of a car where the engine is)
  • ((I looked under the hood and clouds of smoke poured out.::
    我看了一下引擎罩下面，团团的烟冒了出来。))
US
(also 'hood)
贫民区，贫困社区[英]^(a poor neighbourhood)
  • ((When he started he was just a poor boy from the hood - now he's a multimillionaire.::
    他刚起步时只是一个从贫民区来的穷小子——如今他已是个千万富翁了。))

-hood

/ -hʊd// -hʊd/
suffix
（用于构成名词，描述作为某种事物的状态）[英]^(used to form nouns describing the state of being a particular thing)
  • ((priesthood::
    牧师身份))
  • ((childhood/manhood::
    童年／成年时期))
  • ((nationhood::
    国家地位))

horrific

/həˈrɪf.ɪk//həˈrɪf.ɪk/
adjective
极其可怕的；令人震惊的[英]^(very bad and shocking)
  • ((a horrific accident/crime::
    极其可怕的意外事故／骇人的罪行))
  • ((horrific injuries::
    极为严重的伤势))

horrified

/ˈhɒr.ɪ.faɪd//ˈhɔːr.ə.faɪd/
adjective
C2
非常震惊的[英]^(very shocked)
  • ((He looked horrified when I told him.::
    当我告诉他时，他看起来非常震惊。))
  • ((We were horrified at/by the size of the bill.::
    账单的数额让我们非常震惊。))
  • ((I was horrified to hear of his death.::
    听到他的死讯，我非常震惊。))
  • ((I was horrified that they hadn't included you.::
    我很吃惊他们没有把你算进去。))

hub

/hʌb//hʌb/
noun [C]
中心；枢纽[英]^(the central or main part of something where there is most activity)
  • ((The City of London is the hub of the UK's financial world.::
    伦敦城是英国金融业的中心。))
  • ((The computer department is at the hub of the company's operations.::
    计算机部是这家公司运转的枢纽。))
轮毂[英]^(the central part of a wheel into which the spokes (= bars connecting the central part to the outer edge of the wheel) are fixed)

hue

/hjuː//hjuː/
noun [C]
颜色，色彩，色调[英]^((a degree of lightness, darkness, strength, etc. of) a colour)
  • ((In the Caribbean waters there are fish of every hue.::
    加勒比海水域中的鱼五颜六色。))
种类；派别[英]^(a different type or group)
  • ((Politicians of all hues wish to get sleaze off the agenda so that they can discuss the real issues.::
    各个党派的与会者都希望将那些卑劣之事从议事日程中去掉，这样他们就可以讨论真正的问题了。))

hull

/hʌl//hʌl/
noun [C]
船体，船身[英]^(the body or frame of a ship, most of which goes under the water)
verb [T]
除去（水果、蔬菜等的）皮（或茎、叶）[英]^(to remove the covering or the stem and leaves from some fruits, vegetables, and seeds)
  • ((We sat in the garden hulling strawberries.::
    我们坐在园子里摘除草莓蒂。))

Hull

/hʌl//hʌl/
noun
赫尔[英]^(a city in northeast England whose full name is Kingston upon Hull)
  • ((They would travel to Hamburg, then by boat to Hull .::
    他们会先去汉堡，然后坐船去赫尔。))
  • ((We lived in Hull for 17 years.::
    我们在赫尔住了十七年。))

humane

/hjuːˈmeɪn//hjuːˈmeɪn/
adjective
（尤指对待受苦者）善良的，仁慈的，人道的[英]^(showing kindness, care, and sympathy towards others, especially those who are suffering)
  • ((The humane way of dealing with a suffering animal (= the way that causes the least pain) is to kill it quickly.::
    对待为病痛所折磨的动物，比较人道的办法就是尽快结束它的生命。))

humanitarian

/hjuːˌmæn.ɪˈteə.ri.ən//hjuːˌmæn.ɪˈter.i.ən/
adjective, noun [C]
C2
人道主义的;人道主义者[英]^((a person who is) involved in or connected with improving people's lives and reducing suffering)
  • ((The prisoner has been released for humanitarian reasons.::
    出于人道主义原因那名囚犯被释放了。))
  • ((The United Nations is sending humanitarian aid (= food and supplies to help people) to the areas worst affected by the conflict.::
    联合国正在向受冲突影响最为严重的地区输送人道主义援助。))
  • ((The well-known humanitarian, Joseph Rowntree, was concerned with the welfare of his employees.::
    著名的人道主义者约瑟夫‧荣特里非常关心其雇员的福利。))

humanity

/hjuːˈmæn.ə.ti//hjuːˈmæn.ə.t̬i/
noun [U]
C1
（统称）人，人类[英]^(people in general)
  • ((The massacre was a crime against humanity.::
    这次大屠杀犯下了反人类的罪行。))
C2
对他人的理解，仁慈[英]^(understanding and kindness towards other people)
  • ((If only he would show/display a little humanity for once.::
    但愿他这次能表现出一点慈悲。))
C2
人性[英]^(the condition of being human)
  • ((There is a sense of common humanity that unites people of all nations.::
    是对共同人性的认知让各国人民团结起来。))

(the) humanities

/hjuːˈmæn.ə.ti//hjuːˈmæn.ə.t̬i/
noun [plural]
我一直对人文学科比对自然科学更感兴趣。[英]^(the study of subjects such as literature, language, history, and philosophy)
  • ((I've always been more interested in the humanities than the sciences.::
    我一直对人文学科比对自然科学更感兴趣。))

hunch

/hʌntʃ//hʌntʃ/
noun [C]
直觉;预感[英]^(an idea that is based on feeling and for which there is no proof)
  • ((I had a hunch that you'd be here.::
    直觉告诉我你会来这儿。))
  • ((Sometimes you have to be prepared to act on/follow a hunch.::
    有时候你得准备好按直觉行事。))
verb [I or T]
弓（背），弯腰[英]^(to lean forward with your shoulders raised or to bend your back and shoulders into a rounded shape)
  • ((We hunched round the fire to keep warm.::
    我们弓着身子围在火边取暖。))
  • ((Stand up straight and don't hunch your back.::
    站直了，别弯着腰。))

hurdle

/ˈhɜː.dəl//ˈhɝː.dəl/
noun
[C]
（跨栏比赛中的）栏架[英]^(a frame or fence for jumping over in a race)
  • ((He fell at the last hurdle.::
    他在最后一个栏架处摔倒了。))
  • ((She cleared (= jumped over) all the hurdles easily and raced to the finishing line.::
    她轻松地跨过所有栏架到达了终点。))
障碍，难题[英]^(a problem that you have to deal with before you can make progress)
  • ((Getting a work permit was the first hurdle to overcome.::
    取得工作许可证是要解决的第一道难题。))
  • ((The cost of this exercise is proving to be a major hurdle.::
    这种锻炼的费用将是一个很大的难题。))
verb [I or T]
参加跨栏比赛;跨过[英]^(to run in a race in which there are hurdles to be jumped over, or to jump over something while running)
  • ((He hurdled the gate and scrambled up the hill.::
    他翻越大门爬上了山坡。))

hurdles

/ˈhɜː.dəl//ˈhɝː.dəl/
noun [plural]
400米跨栏比赛[英]^(a race in which people or horses jump over hurdles)
  • ((the 400-metre hurdles::
    400米跨栏比赛))

hush

/hʌʃ//hʌʃ/
noun [S or U]
（突然的）寂静，安静[英]^(a sudden, calm silence)
  • ((There was a deathly hush after she made the announcement.::
    她宣读完声明后，现场一片死寂。))
  • ((A hush fell over the room.::
    房间里一片寂静。))
  • ((Let's have some hush, please! (= Be quiet, please!)::
    请安静！))
exclamation
（示意某人安静）嘘[英]^(used to tell someone to be quiet)
  • ((Hush! You'll wake the baby!::
    嘘！你会吵醒婴儿的！))

hype

/haɪp//haɪp/
noun [U]
（新闻媒体的）大肆宣传，炒作[英]^(a situation in which something is advertised and discussed in newspapers, on television, etc. a lot in order to attract everyone's interest)
  • ((media hype::
    媒体炒作))
  • ((There's been a lot of hype around/surrounding his latest film.::
    围绕他的最新影片进行了大规模的宣传。))
  • ((I've been put off reading the book by all the hype.::
    所有的宣传炒作让我对这本书产生了反感。))
verb [T often passive]
(also hype up)
（通过新闻媒体）大肆宣传，炒作[英]^(to repeatedly advertise and discuss something in newspapers, on television, etc. in order to attract everyone's interest)
  • ((It's being hyped as the musical event of the year.::
    它正被炒作成年度音乐盛事。))

hypothetical

/ˌhaɪ.pəˈθet.ɪ.kəl//ˌhaɪ.pəˈθet̬.ɪ.kəl/
adjective
假定的，假设的[英]^(imagined or suggested but not necessarily real or true)
  • ((a hypothetical example/situation::
    假设的例子／情况))
  • ((This is all very hypothetical but supposing Jackie got the job, how would that affect you?::
    这当然全是假设，不过假若杰基得到了那份工作，对你又会有什么影响呢？))

adverb
PUBLISHING
（出处）同前，如上[英]^(used in formal writing to refer to a book or article that has already been mentioned)

id

/ɪd//ɪd/
noun [C]
PSYCHOLOGY
（精神分析中的）本我，伊德（指潜意识的最深层，代表人最基本的需要和情感）[英]^(in psychoanalysis, the deepest part of the unconscious mind that represents the most basic natural human needs and emotions such as hunger, anger, and the wish for pleasure)

  • ((Do you have any ID? A driving licence or cheque card will do.::
    你有身份证明吗？驾照或支票卡都行。))

    该运动内部在意识形态上存在一些比较严重的分歧。))

C1
偶像，明星[英]^(someone who is admired and respected very much)
  • ((a pop/sporting idol::
    流行音乐／体育明星))
  • ((The Hollywood film idols of the 1940s were glamorous figures, adored by millions.::
    20世纪40年代好莱坞的电影明星魅力四射，被无数人所崇拜。))

  • ((The ancient people of this area worshipped a huge bronze idol in the shape of an elephant.::
    这一地区的古代居民膜拜一尊象形的青铜巨像。))

immoral

/ɪˈmɒr.əl//ɪˈmɔːr.əl/
adjective
B2
不道德的，道德败坏的[英]^(morally wrong, or outside society's standards of acceptable, honest, and moral behaviour)
  • ((an immoral act::
    不道德的举动))
  • ((immoral behaviour::
    不道德的行为))
  • ((It's an immoral tax, because the poor will pay relatively more.::
    这是不道德的税收，因为穷人相对要付出更多。))

immoral earnings

/ɪˈmɒr.əl//ɪˈmɔːr.əl/
adjective
UK
如果被判有罪，她可能会因靠卖淫为生坐5年牢。[英]^(money earned from prostitution (= having sex in exchange for money))
  • ((If convicted, she could be jailed for five years for living off immoral earnings.::
    如果被判有罪，她可能会因靠卖淫为生坐5年牢。))

impeach

/ɪmˈpiːtʃ//ɪmˈpiːtʃ/
verb [T]
（尤指在美国）控告，弹劾（公职人员）[英]^(to make a formal statement saying that a public official is guilty of a serious offence in connection with their job, especially in the US)
  • ((The governor was impeached for wrongful use of state money.::
    州长因滥用本州公款而遭到弹劾。))

impede

/ɪmˈpiːd//ɪmˈpiːd/
verb [T]
妨碍，阻碍；阻止[英]^(to make it more difficult for something to happen or more difficult for someone to do something)
  • ((Although he's shy, it certainly hasn't impeded his career in any way.::
    尽管他很害羞，但这显然一点儿也没有妨碍他的事业。))

impending

/ɪmˈpen.dɪŋ//ɪmˈpen.dɪŋ/
adjective [before noun]
（通常指不愉快或不受欢迎的事件）即将发生的，逼近的[英]^(used to refer to an event, usually something unpleasant or unwanted, that is going to happen soon)
  • ((impending disaster/doom::
    即将到来的灾难／劫数))
  • ((The player announced his impending retirement from international football.::
    这位球员宣布他即将从国家队退役。))

implant

verb [T]
/ɪmˈplɑːnt//ɪmˈplænt/
（手术中）植入，移植[英]^(to put an organ, group of cells, or device into the body in a medical operation)
  • ((The owner's name and address is stored on a microchip and implanted in the dog's body.::
    主人的姓名和地址都储存在芯片中，然后植入狗体内。))
灌输[英]^(to fix ideas, feelings, or opinions in someone else's mind)
  • ((He implanted some very strange attitudes in his children.::
    他给他的孩子们灌输了一些奇怪的看法。))
  • ((There is much debate on the issue of "therapists" implanting false memories of sexual abuse in adults.::
    有些“理疗师”给成年人植入有关性虐待的虚假记忆，对此现在有很多争议。))
noun [C]
/ˈɪm.plɑːnt//ˈɪm.plænt/
（手术中）植入，移植[英]^(an organ, group of cells, or device that has been put into the body in a medical operation)
  • ((breast/heart valve implants::
    乳房填充物／人工心脏瓣膜))

implicate

/ˈɪm.plɪ.keɪt//ˈɪm.plə.keɪt/
verb [T]
牵连，涉及[英]^(to show that someone is involved in a crime or partly responsible for something bad that has happened)
  • ((Have they any evidence to implicate him in the robbery?::
    他们有证据表明他涉嫌抢劫案吗？))

impoverish

/ɪmˈpɒv.ər.ɪʃ//ɪmˈpɑː.vɚ.ɪʃ/
verb [T]
使某人穷困[英]^(to make someone very poor)
  • ((The new law is likely to further impoverish single parents.::
    这条新法律有可能使单亲家长进一步穷困。))
  • ((He was made to pay a ruinous fine that impoverished his family.::
    他被迫支付一笔难以承受的罚款，这导致了家庭的穷困。))

imprint

verb [T]
/ɪmˈprɪnt//ɪmˈprɪnt/
印，压印[英]^(to mark a surface by pressing something hard into it)
铭刻，使铭记[英]^(to fix an event or experience so firmly in the memory that it cannot be forgotten although you do not try to remember it)
  • ((That look of grief would be imprinted on her mind forever.::
    那种悲伤的神情会永远印在她的脑海中。))
noun
/ˈɪm.prɪnt//ˈɪm.prɪnt/
[C]
（印在书籍上的）出版者名称[英]^(the name of a publisher as it appears on a particular set of books)
[C usually singular]
压痕，痕迹[英]^(an occasion when an object presses on something and leaves a mark)
  • ((The button had left an imprint on my arm.::
    这只纽扣在我的手臂上留下了一个印痕。))
[S]
深刻印象;持久影响[英]^(an occasion when an event or experience becomes fixed in someone's memory or leaves its mark in some way on their appearance)
  • ((War has left its imprint on the strained faces of these people.::
    战争在这些人饱经沧桑的脸上留下了痕迹。))

improvise

/ˈɪm.prə.vaɪz//ˈɪm.prə.vaɪz/
verb [I or T]
临时做;即兴做[英]^(to invent or make something, such as a speech or a device, at the time when it is needed without already having planned it)
  • ((I hadn't prepared a speech so I suddenly had to improvise.::
    我没有准备演讲，所以突然之间我只得即兴讲几句。))
  • ((We improvised a mattress from a pile of blankets.::
    为了能有地方睡觉，我们临时用一摞毯子作床垫。))
（演员）即兴表演;（音乐家）即兴创作[英]^(When actors or musicians improvise, they perform without prepared speech or music, making up the play, music, etc. as they perform it.)
  • ((During certain scenes of the play there isn't any script and the actors just improvise (the dialogue).::
    这出戏有几场没有剧本，演员们就即兴表演（对白）。))

inadvertent

/ˌɪn.ədˈvɜː.tənt//ˌɪn.ədˈvɝː.t̬ənt/
adjective
非故意的，无意的[英]^(not intentional)
  • ((All authors need to be wary of inadvertent copying of other people's ideas.::
    所有作者都需注意不要在无意中抄袭了他人的观点。))

incarnate

/ɪnˈkɑː.nət//ɪnˈkɑːr.nət/
adjective [after noun]
人体化的，化身的[英]^(in human form)
  • ((One survivor described his torturers as devils incarnate.::
    一名生还者形容拷打他的那些人是魔鬼的化身。))

incinerate

/ɪnˈsɪn.ər.eɪt//ɪnˈsɪn.ə.reɪt/
verb [T]
把…烧成灰烬，焚毁[英]^(to burn something completely)
  • ((to incinerate waste::
    焚烧废弃物))
  • ((The spacecraft and its crew were incinerated by the billion-degree temperatures generated by the fireball.::
    航天器以及全体宇航员被火球产生的10亿度的高温化为了灰烬。))

incise

/ɪnˈsaɪz//ɪnˈsaɪz/
verb [T usually passive]
雕，刻[英]^(to cut the surface of something carefully with a sharp tool)
  • ((The design is incised into a metal plate.::
    这图案是刻在金属板上的。))
  • ((a shield incised with Celtic symbols::
    刻有凯尔特人符号的盾牌))

incomprehensible

/ɪnˌkɒm.prɪˈhen.sə.bəl//ɪnˌkɑːm.prəˈhen.sə.bəl/
adjective
不能理解的;极难懂的[英]^(impossible or extremely difficult to understand)
  • ((These accounts are utterly incomprehensible. Can you explain them to me?::
    这些账目根本就看不懂。你能给我解释一下吗？))
  • ((It's incomprehensible to me why he would want to kill himself.::
    我无法理解他为什么要自杀。))

increment

/ˈɪŋ.krə.mənt/
noun [C]
增加，增长[英]^(one of a series of increases)
  • ((You will receive annual salary/pay increments every September.::
    每年9月你会得到加薪。))

incubate

/ˈɪŋ.kjə.beɪt//ˈɪŋ.kjə.beɪt/
verb [I or T]
孵（卵），孵化[英]^(When a bird, etc. incubates its eggs, it keeps them warm until the young come out, and when eggs incubate, they develop to the stage at which the young come out.)
  • ((The female bird incubates the eggs for about 16 days.::
    雌鸟孵卵16天左右。))
（细菌或病毒在体内）潜伏[英]^(When harmful bacteria or viruses incubate, or when a person or animal incubates them, they increase in size or number in the person's or animal's body but do not yet produce the effects of disease.)

incumbent

/ɪnˈkʌm.bənt//ɪnˈkʌm.bənt/
adjective [before noun]
现任的;在职的[英]^(officially having the named position)
  • ((The incumbent president faces problems which began many years before he took office.::
    现任总统面临着他上任前很多年就已开始出现的种种问题。))
noun [C]
现任者，在职者[英]^(the person who has or had a particular official position)
  • ((the first/last/previous incumbent::
    第一任／上一任／前任))
  • ((The present incumbent (of the post) is due to retire next month.::
    （此职位的）现任者将于下个月退休。))

be incumbent on/upon someone

/ɪnˈkʌm.bənt//ɪnˈkʌm.bənt/
adjective
她感到她有义务在他们的会上提出这个问题。[英]^(to be necessary for someone)
  • ((She felt it incumbent upon/on her to raise the subject at their meeting.::
    她感到她有义务在他们的会上提出这个问题。))

indict

/ɪnˈdaɪt//ɪnˈdaɪt/
verb [T]
LAW
控告，告发;起诉[英]^(If a law court or a grand jury indicts someone, it accuses them officially of a crime.)
  • ((He was indicted on drug charges at Snaresbrook Crown Court.::
    在斯奈尔斯布鲁克刑事法庭他被起诉犯有与毒品有关的罪行。))
  • ((Five people were indicted for making and selling counterfeit currency.::
    5人因制售假钞被起诉。))

indigenous

/ɪnˈdɪdʒ.ɪ.nəs//ɪnˈdɪdʒ.ə.nəs/
adjective
当地的;本土的，土生土长的[英]^(used to refer to plants and animals that grow or live naturally in a place, and have not been brought there from somewhere else)
  • ((Are there any species of frog indigenous to the area?::
    这一地区是否有本地品种的青蛙？))
  • The snakes are a serious threat to indigenous wildlife owing to their big appetites.

indirect

/ˌɪn.daɪˈrekt/ˌɪn.dɪˈrekt//ˌɪn.dɪˈrekt/ˌɪn.daɪˈrekt/
adjective
C2
间接的[英]^(happening in addition to an intended result, often in a way that is complicated or not obvious)
  • ((The benefits from pure research are often indirect.::
    纯理论研究带来的益处常常是间接的。))
  • ((Indirect effects of the fighting include disease and food shortages.::
    战争的间接后果包括疾病肆虐及食品短缺。))
旁敲侧击的[英]^(avoiding clearly mentioning or saying something)
  • ((indirect criticism::
    旁敲侧击的批评))
C1
迂回的，曲折的[英]^(not following a straight line, or not directly or simply connected)
  • ((to take an indirect route/flight::
    走迂回路线／乘非直达航班))

induct

/ɪnˈdʌkt//ɪnˈdʌkt/
verb [T]
使正式就任;正式吸收…为会员;使入门;传授[英]^(to introduce someone formally or with a special ceremony to an organization or group, or to beliefs or ideas)
  • ((Li Xiannian was inducted into the Politburo in 1956.::
    李先念于1956年进入政治局。))

infantry

/ˈɪn.fən.tri//ˈɪn.fən.tri/
noun [U, + sing/pl verb]
步兵，步兵团[英]^(the part of an army that fights on foot)
  • ((The infantry was/were sent into battle.::
    步兵团被派往战场。))
  • ((It's a light/heavy infantry unit.::
    这是一个轻／重型步兵团。))

infiltrate

/ˈɪn.fɪl.treɪt//ˈɪn.fɪl.treɪt/
verb [I + adv/prep, T]
（使）潜入；（使）渗透[英]^(to secretly become part of a group in order to get information or to influence the way that group thinks or behaves)
  • ((A journalist managed to infiltrate the powerful drug cartel.::
    一位记者设法打入了势力强大的贩毒集团内部。))
渗透（入某物质、地方、系统或机构）[英]^(to move slowly into a substance, place, system, or organization)
  • ((At about this time the new ideas about "corporate management" had begun to infiltrate (into) local government.::
    大约此时，有关“共同管理”的一些新思想逐步开始为当地政府所接受。))

inflame

/ɪnˈfleɪm//ɪnˈfleɪm/
verb [T or I]
激起（愤怒、激动等情感）；使愤怒；使极度激动；给…火上浇油[英]^(to cause or increase very strong feelings such as anger or excitement)
  • ((Reducing the number of staff is certain to inflame the already angry medical profession.::
    裁员一定会使本已不满的医务人员更加愤怒。))
  • Pictures of the bombed and burning city inflamed passions further.
  • The image was used to inflame rather than instruct or reveal truth.

influx

/ˈɪn.flʌks//ˈɪn.flʌks/
noun [C usually singular]
C2
涌进;汇集[英]^(the fact of a large number of people or things arriving at the same time)
  • ((Turkey is expecting an influx of several thousand refugees over the next few days.::
    未来几天涌入土耳其的难民预计会达几千人。))

informal

/ɪnˈfɔː.məl//ɪnˈfɔːr.məl/
adjective
B2
非正式的，非正规的;（服装）日常使用的;（言行）随意的[英]^(not formal or official)
  • ((The two groups agreed to hold an informal meeting.::
    两个集团同意举行一次非正式会议。))
  • Alliances among small businesses are often informal arrangements, such as two companies teaming up for a marketing event.

infringe

/ɪnˈfrɪndʒ//ɪnˈfrɪndʒ/
verb [T]
违反，违背（规定、法律等）[英]^(to break a rule, law, etc.)
  • ((They infringed building regulations.::
    他们违反了建筑规章。))

infuse

/ɪnˈfjuːz//ɪnˈfjuːz/
verb
[T + prep]
使（某人）充满（某种感情）；将（某特性）注入（某物）[英]^(to fill someone or something with an emotion or quality)
  • ((The pulling down of the Berlin Wall infused the world with optimism.::
    柏林墙的倒塌使全世界欢欣鼓舞。))
  • ((The arrival of a group of friends on Saturday infused new life into the weekend.::
    星期六一群朋友的到来给周末生活注入了新的活力。))
[I or T]
泡（茶）;泡制（草药）[英]^(If you infuse a drink or it infuses, you leave substances such as tea leaves or herbs in hot water so that their flavour goes into the liquid.)
  • ((Allow the tea to infuse for five minutes.::
    让茶泡5分钟。))

injunction

/ɪnˈdʒʌŋk.ʃən//ɪnˈdʒʌŋk.ʃən/
noun [C]
禁令[英]^(an official order given by a law court, usually to stop someone from doing something)
  • ((The court has issued an injunction to prevent the airline from increasing its prices.::
    法院颁布禁令不准航空公司提价。))
  • ((She is seeking an injunction banning the newspaper from publishing the photographs.::
    她正在争取获得禁令，禁止报纸发表这些照片。))

  • ((The prize winners each receive a book with their names inscribed on the first page.::
    每名获奖者都得到一本首页题有他们签名的书。))
  • ((The wall of the church was inscribed with the names of the dead from World War I.::
    教堂墙壁上镌刻着第一次世界大战中死难者的名字。))

  • ((The inscriptions on the gravestones were worn away.::
    墓碑上的碑文已经消蚀了。))

/ˈɪn.sjə.lɪn//ˈɪn.sə.lɪn/

CHEMISTRY • BIOLOGY • MEDICAL

  • ((She has to have insulin injections for her diabetes.::
    她因患有糖尿病必须注射胰岛素。))

  • ((Law enforcement agents intercepted a shipment of drugs from Central America.::

  • ((Barry intercepted Naylor's pass and scored the third goal.::
    巴里断下内勒尔的传球，射入了第3个球。))

intern

verb [T often passive]
/ɪnˈtɜːn//ɪnˈtɝːn/

    战争期间许多外国人被拘禁。))

/ˈɪn.tɜːn//ˈɪn.tɝːn/

interrogate

/ɪnˈter.ə.ɡeɪt//ɪnˈter.ə.ɡeɪt/
verb [T]
讯问，审问，盘问[英]^(to ask someone a lot of questions for a long time in order to get information, sometimes using threats or violence)
  • ((Thousands of dissidents have been interrogated or imprisoned in recent weeks.::
    数千名持不同政见者在最近几周遭到审问或拘禁。))
COMPUTING
（在计算机上）查询[英]^(to get information from a computer)
  • The computer language was originally developed to make it faster to interrogate a database.

intersect

/ˌɪn.təˈsekt//ˌɪn.t̬ɚˈsekt/
verb
[I or T]
（线条、道路等）（和…）相交，（和…）交叉[英]^((of lines, roads, etc.) to cross one another)
  • ((The roads intersect near the bridge.::
    这些道路在大桥附近相交。))
  • This is the point where the line intersects the curve.
[T]
贯穿，横穿[英]^(to divide an area into smaller parts by crossing it with straight lines)
  • ((The gardens are intersected by gravel paths.::
    这些花园里碎石小道纵横交错。))

intestine

/ɪnˈtes.tɪn//ɪnˈtes.tɪn/
noun [C usually plural]

  • ((Antibodies from the mother's milk line the baby's intestines and prevent infection.::
    来自母乳的抗体遍布在婴儿的肠道中，能防止感染。))

intolerable

/ɪnˈtɒl.ər.ə.bəl//ɪnˈtɑː.lɚ.ə.bəl/

  • ((The situation has become intolerable.::

  • ((The constant fighting made life at home intolerable.::
    持续不断的争吵使家庭生活变得无法忍受。))

    世界上3/4的人口生活在西方人会感到难以忍受的环境中。))

intuitive

/ɪnˈtʃuː.ɪ.tɪv//ɪnˈtuː.ɪ.t̬ɪv/
adjective

  • ((an intuitive approach/judgment::
    凭直觉的方法／判断))
  • ((Most people have an intuitive sense of right and wrong.::
    大多数人具有基于直觉的是非感。))
凭直觉能知晓的[英]^(able to know or understand something because of feelings rather than facts or proof)
  • Good agents are certainly extroverted, but are grounded, rather than intuitive.

involuntary

/ɪnˈvɒl.ən.tər.i//ɪnˈvɑː.lən.ter.i/
adjective
非自愿的;不由自主的，无意识的[英]^(not done by choice; done unwillingly, or without the decision or intention of the person involved)
  • ((A sharp tap on the knee usually causes an involuntary movement of the lower leg.::
    突然轻轻敲一下膝盖，小腿通常会不由自主地动一下。))

iron

/aɪən//aɪrn/
noun
B1 [U]
(symbol Fe)
铁[英]^(a chemical element that is a common greyish-coloured metal. It is strong, used in making steel, and exists in very small amounts in blood.)
  • ((Iron rusts easily.::
    铁易生锈。))
  • ((Liver is a particularly rich source of dietary iron.::
    肝脏中含有特别丰富的可食用铁质。))
  • ((iron ore::
    铁矿))
  • ((an iron deficiency::
    铁质缺乏))
B1 [C]
熨斗[英]^(a piece of equipment for making clothes flat and smooth that has a handle and a flat base and is usually heated with electricity)
  • ((a steam iron::
    蒸汽熨斗))
  • ((a travel iron::
    旅行用熨斗))
[C]
（高尔夫球运动中的）铁头球杆，铁杆[英]^(a stick that has an iron or steel part at the end that is used to hit the ball in golf)
  • ((He'll probably use a 2 or 3 iron for the shot.::
    他这一击很可能要用2号或3号铁头球杆。))
verb [I or T]
B1
熨（衣），烫平[英]^(to make clothes flat and smooth using an iron)
  • ((It takes about five minutes to iron a shirt properly.::
    熨好一件衬衣大约需要5分钟。))
adjective [before noun]
极强壮的；强硬坚定的[英]^(very strong physically, mentally, or emotionally)
  • ((I think you have to have an iron will to make some of these decisions.::
    我认为你得有钢铁般的意志才能作出这些决定。))

  • ((It was common practice for the prisoners to be clapped in irons (= tied with chains).::
    通常会用镣铐铐住犯人。))

irresistible

/ˌɪr.ɪˈzɪs.tə.bəl//ˌɪr.əˈzɪs.tə.bəl/

C2

  • ((an irresistible offer::

  • ((She gave me one of those irresistible smiles and I just had to agree.::
    她对我那莞尔一笑真是令人无法抗拒，我只好同意了。))

B2

  • ((I can't wear wool - it makes me itch.::
    我不能穿毛料衣服——穿了就浑身发痒。))

    我脖子后面有一处发痒。))

jelly

/ˈdʒel.i//ˈdʒel.i/
noun
A2 [C or U]
果酱[英]^(a sweet soft food made by cooking fruit with sugar to preserve it. It is smooth, without any pieces of fruit in it. Jelly is eaten on bread.)
  • ((a peanut butter and jelly sandwich::
    花生酱和果酱三明治))
  • ((apple jelly::
    苹果酱))
[C or U] UK
(US trademark Jell-O)
果冻[英]^(a soft, sweet, usually brightly coloured food made from sugar, gelatine, and fruit flavours, that shakes slightly when it is moved)
  • ((I've made a strawberry jelly for the children's tea.::
    我做了份草莓果冻给孩子们当茶点。))
  • ((jelly and ice cream::
    果冻和冰激凌))
[U]
胶冻，胶状物[英]^(any soft, slightly wet substance that shakes slightly when it is moved)
  • ((Frogs' eggs are covered in a sort of transparent jelly.::
    青蛙卵上覆盖着一种透明的胶状物。))

in jeopardy

/ˈdʒep.ə.di//ˈdʒep.ɚ.di/

  • ((The lives of thousands of birds are in jeopardy as a result of the oil spill.::
    石油泄漏使成千上万只鸟的生命受到威胁。))

jerk

/dʒɜːk//dʒɝːk/
verb [I or T, usually + adv/prep]
（使）猝然一动;猛推;急拉[英]^(to make a short sudden movement, or to cause someone or something to do this)
  • ((The car made a strange noise and then jerked to a halt.::
    汽车发出一声怪响，接着猛然停住了。))
  • (("What's wrong?" she asked, jerking her head up.::
    “怎么了？”她猛地扬起头问道。))
noun [C]
猛的一动;急拉;急抽[英]^(a quick sudden movement)
  • ((She pulled the bush out of the ground with a sharp jerk.::
    她猛一使劲把灌木从地里拔了出来。))
  • ((The alarm went off and he woke up with a jerk.::
    闹钟响后他猛然惊醒。))
(US also jerk-off)
（通常指男子）蠢人，头脑简单的人[英]^(a stupid person, usually a man)
  • ((You stupid jerk! You've just spilled beer all down my new shirt!::
    你这个笨蛋！你把啤酒全洒在我的新衬衫上了！))

jersey

/ˈdʒɜː.zi//ˈdʒɝː.zi/
noun
[C]
针织紧身套衫[英]^(a piece of wool or cotton clothing that is worn on the upper part of the body and has sleeves but no opening at the front)
[C]
（体育运动队队员穿的）运动衫[英]^(a shirt that is worn by a member of a sports team)
[U]
细而柔软的布料[英]^(soft thin cloth, usually made from wool, cotton, or silk, that is used for making clothes)
  • ((100 percent cotton jersey::
    含棉量100%的细柔棉织物))

Jersey

/ˈdʒɜː.zi//ˈdʒɝː.zi/
noun
泽西岛（位于英吉利海峡，是海峡群岛中最大的岛屿）[英]^(an island in the English Channel. It is the largest of the group of islands known as the Channel Islands.)
  • ((We stayed at the Mayfair Hotel in St Helier, Jersey.::
    我们住在泽西岛圣赫利尔的梅菲尔酒店里。))
  • ((The company is based on Jersey in the Channel Islands.::
    该公司总部设在海峡群岛的泽西岛。))
[C]
泽西牛（一种产优质奶的浅棕色奶牛）[英]^(a type of pale brown cow that produces milk that is rich in cream)

jockey

/ˈdʒɒk.i//ˈdʒɑː.ki/
noun [C]
职业赛马骑师[英]^(a person whose job is riding horses in races)
  • ((a champion jockey::
    职业赛马冠军骑手))
US
（设备、车辆、物件的）操作者;对…非常感兴趣的人[英]^(a person whose job involves the use of a particular device, vehicle, object, etc., or who is very interested in a particular thing)
  • ((a desk jockey::
    案牍工作的人))
  • ((a computer jockey::
    计算机操作员))
verb [I]
运用各种手段谋利[英]^(to attempt to get power or get into a better position than other people using any methods you can)
  • ((Since the death of the president, opposition parties and the army have been jockeying for power.::
    总统死后，各反对党和军队一直在争权夺利。))
  • ((As the singer came on stage, the photographers jockeyed for position at the front of the hall.::
    歌星一上台，摄影师就在演播厅前部争抢位置。))

jolt

/dʒəʊlt//dʒoʊlt/
verb
[I or T, usually + adv/prep]
（使）震动，（使）猛然摇动[英]^(to (cause something or someone to) move suddenly and violently)
  • ((The train stopped unexpectedly and we were jolted forwards.::
    火车突然停住了，我们都猛地向前晃了一下。))
  • ((The truck jolted along the rough track through the field.::
    卡车沿着田野里崎岖的小路颠簸前行。))
[T]
使震惊[英]^(to shock someone in order to change their behaviour or way of thinking)
  • ((The charity used photos of starving children in an attempt to jolt the public conscience (= make people feel guilty and take action).::
    慈善机构用饥饿儿童的照片来触动公众的良知。))
noun [C]
震动，剧烈晃动;颠簸[英]^(a sudden violent movement)
  • ((As the plane touched the ground, there was a massive jolt and we were thrown forwards.::
    飞机着陆时剧烈震动，我们被猛地甩向前方。))
  • ((I woke up with a jolt as I thought I heard my bedroom door being pushed open.::
    我好像听到自己卧室的门被推开，猛地惊醒了。))
震惊，惊讶[英]^(an unpleasant shock or surprise)
  • ((His self-confidence took a sudden jolt with the news that he had not been selected.::
    他未被选中的消息使他的自信心遭受意外打击。))

jolt someone into/out of something

/dʒəʊlt//dʒoʊlt/
verb
萨姆生病的消息使她猛醒，开始采取行动。[英]^(to give someone a sudden shock that forces them to act)
  • ((The news about Sam's illness jolted her into action.::
    萨姆生病的消息使她猛醒，开始采取行动。))

judiciary

/dʒuːˈdɪʃ.ər.i//dʒuːˈdɪ.ʃi.er.i/
noun [C, + sing/pl verb]

  • ((a member of the judiciary::
    司法部成员))

juggle

/ˈdʒʌɡ.əl//ˈdʒʌɡ.əl/
verb
[I or T]
（用…）玩杂耍[英]^(to throw several objects up into the air, and then catch and throw them up repeatedly so that one or more stays in the air, usually in order to entertain people)
  • ((We all watched in amazement as he juggled with three flaming torches.::
    他拿3个燃烧的火把玩杂耍，我们都看呆了。))
C2 [T]
尽力同时应付（两种或两种以上不同的活动或人）[英]^(to succeed in arranging your life so that you have time to involve yourself in two or more different activities or groups of people)
  • ((Many parents find it hard to juggle children and a career.::
    许多父母发现一边照顾孩子一边忙事业很难应付。))
[T]
歪曲，篡改[英]^(to change results or information recorded as numbers so that a situation seems to be better than it really is)
  • ((It won't matter if we juggle the figures - no one will know.::
    我们改动这些数字没关系——没人会知道的。))

justly

/ˈdʒʌst.li//ˈdʒʌst.li/
adverb
公正地，公平地;正义地[英]^(in a fair or morally correct way)
  • ((He was justly condemned to a long prison sentence.::
    他被判处长期监禁，判决十分公正。))
  • ((Kenji Mizoguchi is justly recognized as one of Japanese cinema’s greatest figures.::
    沟口健二被公认为是日本电影界最伟大的人物之一。))

kid

/kɪd//kɪd/
noun
B1 [C]
小孩[英]^(a child)
  • ((He took the kids to the park while I was working.::
    我工作时他把孩子们带到公园去了。))
[C]
年轻人[英]^(a young person)
  • ((He was only 16, just a kid really.::
    他才16岁，还是个毛头小子。))
  • ((What's up, kid?::
    年轻人，怎么啦？))
[C]
小山羊，小羚羊[英]^(a young goat)
[U]
小山羊皮革[英]^(very soft leather made from the skin of a young goat)
  • ((kid gloves::
    小山羊皮手套))
verb [I or T]
-dd-
（与某人）开玩笑;哄骗[英]^(to say something as a joke, often making someone believe something that is not true)
  • ((Oh no, I forgot your birthday! Hey, just/only kidding!::
    啊，我把你的生日忘了！嘿，开玩笑的！))
  • ((You won first prize? You're kidding! (= I'm really surprised.)::
    你得了第一？开玩笑吧！))
  • ((I'm just kidding you!::
    我不过和你开个玩笑！))

someone's kid sister/brother

/kɪd//kɪd/
noun
US
someone's younger sister or brother
  • I went to Florida to visit my kid brother and his family.

be like a kid in a candy store

/kɪd//kɪd/
noun
US, Australian English
你真应该看看他们来的时候他的样子，简直就像是进了糖果店的孩子。[英]^(to be very happy and excited about the things around you, and often react to them in a way that is silly and not controlled)
  • ((You should have seen him when they arrived. He was like a kid in a candy store.::
    你真应该看看他们来的时候他的样子，简直就像是进了糖果店的孩子。))

kid yourself

/kɪd//kɪd/
verb [I or T]
-dd-
欺骗自已[英]^(to believe something that is not true, usually because you want it to be true)
  • ((He says there's a good chance she'll come back to him but I think he's kidding himself.::
    他说她很可能会回到他身边，但我觉得他是在自欺欺人。))
  • If you think he's going to buy that excuse, you're kidding yourself.
  • Don't kid yourself: no matter how hard you work, they aren't going to promote you.

  • ((Stella has very kindly offered to help out with the food for the party.::
    斯特拉很友善，主动提出帮忙准备聚会的食物。))

  • ((You are kindly requested to leave the building.::
    请你离开这座房子。))

  • ((a kindly old lady::

/naɪt//naɪt/
noun [C]
（英国的）爵士[英]^(a man given a rank of honour by a British king or queen because of his special achievements, and who has the right to be called "Sir")
  • ((He hopes to be made a knight for his work at the Bank of England.::
    他希望因为他在英格兰银行的工作而被封为爵士。))
（旧时的）骑士[英]^((in the past) a man of high social position trained to fight as a soldier on a horse)
  • ((knights in black armour::
    身着黑色盔甲的骑士))

  • ((He was knighted for his work with famine victims.::
    他为饥荒难民操劳而受封为爵士。))

/ˈleɪ.dən//ˈleɪ.dən/

  • ((He always comes back from France laden with presents for everyone.::
    他从法国回来总是给大家带很多礼物。))
  • ((The table, as always, was laden with food.::
    与以往一样，桌子上摆满了食物。))

lament

/ləˈment//ləˈment/
verb [I or T]
对…感到悲痛，对…表示失望，痛惜[英]^(to express sadness and feeling sorry about something)
  • ((The poem opens by lamenting (over) the death of a young man.::
    这首诗的开篇表达了对一位青年之死的惋惜之情。))
  • ((My grandmother, as usual, lamented the decline in moral standards in today's society.::
    和往常一样，我奶奶对当今社会世风日下深感痛惜。))
  • ((The late lamented (= dead and remembered with love) Frank Giotto used to live here.::
    已故的受人爱戴的弗兰克‧焦托曾在此居住。))
noun [C]
挽歌;悼诗;悼文[英]^(a song, poem, or other piece of writing that expresses sadness about someone's death)
  • ((The whole play can be interpreted as a lament for lost youth.::
    整部剧可以看作是一首青春的挽歌。))

lance

/lɑːns//læns/
noun [C]
长矛[英]^(a long, thin pole with a sharp point that soldiers used in the past as a weapon when riding horses)
verb [T]
切开，划开（感染处放脓）[英]^(to cut the skin with a sharp tool in order to release infected matter that has collected under it)
  • ((She had a boil lanced at the doctor's this morning.::
    今天早晨她去诊所切开了一个疖子放脓。))

landmark

/ˈlænd.mɑːk//ˈlænd.mɑːrk/
noun [C]
C1
地标;标志性建筑[英]^(a building or place that is easily recognized, especially one that you can use to judge where you are)
  • ((The Rock of Gibraltar is one of Europe's most famous landmarks.::
    直布罗陀岩山是欧洲最著名的地标之一。))
C2
（发展过程中的）里程碑[英]^(an important stage in something's development)
  • ((The invention of the silicon chip was a landmark in the history of the computer.::
    硅片的发明是计算机发展史上的一个里程碑。))
  • ((In a landmark case/decision, the governor pardoned a woman convicted of killing her husband, who had physically abused her.::
    在一起具有标志性意义的案例／判决中，州长赦免了一位因遭受虐待而杀夫的妇女。))

/ˈlɑː.və//-viː//ˈlɑːr.və/

plural larvae
幼体，幼虫[英]^(a form of an insect or an animal such as a frog that has left its egg but has not yet developed into a pupa or adult insect or animal)

last

/lɑːst//læst/
adjective, adverb, pronoun, noun
A2
最终的;最后的[英]^((the person or thing) after everyone or everything else)
  • ((I hate being the last one to arrive at a meeting.::
    我不愿意开会时最后一个到。))
  • ((Our house is the last one on the left before the traffic lights.::
    我们家是交通信号灯前左侧的最后一家。))
  • ((The Mets will surely finish the season in last place (= at the lowest rank of their division).::
    梅茨队本赛季肯定要垫底了。))
  • ((I know Johnson finished last in the race, but who was second to last (= the one before the one at the end)?::
    我知道约翰逊在比赛中倒数第一，但谁是倒数第二呢？))
  • ((I don't know why he bothers to bet - his horses always come in last.::
    我不明白他为什么还要去下注——他选的马总是落在最后面。))
  • ((At the last moment (= as late as possible) he changed his mind.::
    在最后一刻他改了主意。))
  • ((He always leaves important decisions to the last (possible) moment (= as late as possible).::
    在重大问题上他总要拖到最后一刻才作决定。))
adjective, pronoun, noun [before noun], [U]
B1
最后的，最末的;最后的一个（或一部分）[英]^((being) the only one or part that is left)
  • ((Do you mind if I have the last chocolate?::
    你介意我把最后一块巧克力吃了吗？))
  • ((I'm down to my last dollar - could I borrow some money for lunch?::
    我只剩最后一美元了——我能借点钱吃午饭吗？))
  • ((I'm afraid Martha's eaten the last of the ice cream.::
    恐怕玛莎已经把最后一块冰激凌吃掉了。))
  • ((She was the last of the great educational reformers.::
    她是唯一健在的伟大的教育改革家。))
adjective, adverb, pronoun
A1
上一次的;最近的;最后的[英]^((being) the most recent or the one before the present one)
  • ((Did you hear the storm last night (= during the previous night)?::
    你听到昨晚的暴风雨声了吗？))
  • ((Did you see the news on TV last night (= yesterday evening)?::
    昨晚那条电视新闻你看了吗？))
  • ((They got married last November.::
    去年11月他们结婚了。))
  • ((When was the last time you had a cigarette?::
    你上一次吸烟是在什么时候？))
  • ((When did you last have a cigarette?::
    你最后一次吸烟是在什么时候？))
  • ((She's been working there for the last month (= for the four weeks until now).::
    上个月起她一直在那里工作。))
  • ((Could you account for your whereabouts on Sunday last?::
    你能说说上个星期天你都去什么地方了吗？))
  • ((The/These last five years have been very difficult for him.::
    过去的5年他过得非常艰难。))
  • ((The last we heard of her, she was working as an English teacher in France.::
    上一次我们听到她的消息，她是在法国当英语教师。))
  • ((Each of her paintings has been better than the last.::
    她的油画作品一幅比一幅有进步。))
verb [I, L only + noun]
B1
持续，延续，继续[英]^(to continue to exist)
  • ((The meeting lasted two hours.::
    会议持续了两个小时。))
  • ((The drought lasted for several months.::
    干旱持续了好几个月。))
  • ((They say the snow will last until the end of next week.::
    他们说这场雪要一直下到下周末。))
  • ((I can't see the ceasefire lasting.::
    我认为停火不会持续下去。))
  • ((They haven't had an argument for two weeks, but it's too good to last (= they'll have an argument soon).::
    他们已经两周没吵架了，但这种状态恐怕持续不了多久。))
  • ((I doubt their enthusiasm will last.::
    我怀疑他们只是一时的心血来潮。))
  • ((He's working very efficiently at the moment, but it won't last.::
    目前他的工作效率很高，但不会持续很久。))
C1
维持，保持[英]^(to continue being good or suitable)
  • ((There's no point buying something that isn't going to last.::
    买些不耐用的东西根本毫无意义。))
  • ((The cheaper washing machines should last about five years.::
    比较便宜的洗衣机大约可以使用5年。))
  • ((This pen should last (you) a lifetime if you take care of it.::
    如果注意爱护，这支钢笔可以用上一辈子。))
  • ((Her previous secretary only lasted a month (= left after this period).::
    她的前任秘书只干了1个月。))

at (long) last

/lɑːst//læst/
adjective, adverb, pronoun, noun
B1
我终于把论文写完了！[英]^(finally)
  • ((I've finished my essay at last!::
    我终于把论文写完了！))

the last person, thing, etc.

  • ((Three extra people to feed - that's the last thing I need!::
    再多养活3口人——我可受不了！))

last thing (at night)

/lɑːst//læst/
adjective, adverb, pronoun, noun
UK
晚上睡觉前我会开启洗衣机，这样等我早晨起床后衣服就洗好了。[英]^(at the latest time in the day)
  • ((I'll switch on the washing machine last thing so it'll be finished when I get up in the morning.::
    晚上睡觉前我会开启洗衣机，这样等我早晨起床后衣服就洗好了。))

the last time

/lɑːst//læst/
adjective, adverb, pronoun, noun
他甚至从未向我表示过感谢，所以那是我最后一次帮他。[英]^(If you say that it is the last time you will do something, you mean that you will never do it again)
  • ((He never even thanked me, so that's the last time I do him a favour.::
    他甚至从未向我表示过感谢，所以那是我最后一次帮他。))

/lætʃ//lætʃ/

你如果在我回来之前上床睡觉，别忘了给我留着前门。[英]^(closed but not locked)

    你如果在我回来之前上床睡觉，别忘了给我留着前门。))

/ˈlæv.ɪn.dər//ˈlæv.ɪn.dɚ/

  • ((a lavender bush::

lavish

/ˈlæv.ɪʃ//ˈlæv.ɪʃ/
adjective
C2
奢华的，豪华的[英]^(large in quantity and expensive or impressive)
  • ((lavish gifts/promises/praise::
    奢华的礼物／慷慨的允诺／毫不吝惜的赞扬))
  • ((lavish spending::
    铺张的开支))
  • ((lavish banquets::
    豪华的宴会))
  • ((The evening was a lavish affair with glorious food and an endless supply of champagne.::
    晚会很豪华，食物精美可口，香槟酒源源不断。))
  • ((The lavish production makes this musical truly memorable.::
    这部音乐剧的豪华制作阵容给人留下了深刻印象。))

  • ((The critics were lavish in their praise for the paintings.::
    艺术评论人对这幅油画大加赞赏。))

(UK usually lead)

legion

/ˈliː.dʒən//ˈliː.dʒən/
noun [C]
（尤指古罗马的）军团[英]^(a large group of soldiers who form a part of an army, especially the ancient Roman army)
  • ((Caesar's legions marched through France and crossed into Britain.::
    恺撒的军团穿过法国进入英国。))

大量的，众多的[英]^(very large in number)
  • ((The difficulties surrounding the court case are legion.::
    这个庭审案件困难重重。))

legions of someone

/ˈliː.dʒən//ˈliː.dʒən/
noun [C]
他没有在音乐会上露面，这让等在场外的众多歌迷感到非常失望。[英]^(large numbers of people)
  • ((He failed to turn up for the concert, disappointing the legions of fans waiting outside.::
    他没有在音乐会上露面，这让等在场外的众多歌迷感到非常失望。))

legislature

/ˈledʒ.ɪ.slə.tʃʊər//ˈledʒ.ə.slə.tʃɚ/
noun [C, + sing/pl verb]
立法机构[英]^(the group of people in a country or part of a country who have the power to make and change laws)

lesbian

/ˈlez.bi.ən//ˈlez.bi.ən/
noun [C]
女同性恋者[英]^(a woman who is sexually or romantically attracted to other women and not to people of other genders)
  • gay men and lesbians

lesion

/ˈliː.ʒən//ˈliː.ʒən/
noun [C]
MEDICAL
（对人体或体内器官的）伤害，损伤[英]^(an injury to a person's body or to an organ inside their body)
  • ((skin/brain lesions::
    皮肤／大脑损伤))

lethal

/ˈliː.θəl//ˈliː.θəl/
adjective
C2
致命的;极其危险的[英]^(able to cause or causing death; extremely dangerous)
  • ((Three minutes after the fire started, the house was full of lethal fumes.::
    起火3分钟后，房子里充满了致命的毒气。))
  • ((In the car the police found guns, knives, and other lethal weapons (= weapons that can kill).::
    警察在车里找到了枪支、刀具及其他一些凶器。))
  • ((A 59-year-old man was executed by lethal injection (= by having a poisonous substance put into his body) this morning.::
    今晨一位59岁的男性罪犯被执行注射死刑。))
  • ((That combination of tiredness and alcohol is lethal (= has a very bad effect).::
    身体的疲劳加上酒精的作用会产生非常严重的后果。))

lettuce

/ˈlet.ɪs//ˈlet̬.ɪs/
noun [C or U]
B1
生菜;莴苣[英]^(a plant with large, green leaves, eaten uncooked in salads)

liaison

/liˈeɪ.zɒn//liˈeɪ.zɑːn/
noun
[S or U]
联络，联系，沟通[英]^(communication between people or groups who work with each other)
  • ((He blamed the lack of liaison between the various government departments.::
    他指责各个政府部门之间缺乏沟通。))
  • ((The police have appointed a liaison officer to work with the local community.::
    警方已指派了一名联络官与当地社区进行合作。))
[C] US
联络官，联络人[英]^(someone who helps groups to work effectively with each other)
  • ((She served as a liaison between the different groups.::
    她充当各团体之间的联络人。))
[C]
（尤指婚外的）性关系;私通;婚外情[英]^(a sexual relationship, especially between two people not married to each other)
  • ((He's had a number of liaisons.::
    他已发生了好几段婚外情。))
[U] • PHONETICS
连音[英]^(the act of joining sounds together, for example pronouncing a consonant that is not usually pronounced at the end of a word, because the next word begins with a vowel sound)

lieutenant

/lefˈten.ənt//luːˈten.ənt/
noun [C]
(also Lieutenant)
中尉[英]^((the title of) an officer of middle rank in the armed forces)
  • ((first/second lieutenant::
    （美国）中尉／少尉))
  • ((He was promoted to the rank of lieutenant.::
    他被升为中尉。))
  • ((Lieutenant Woods/Charles Woods::
    伍兹/查尔斯·伍兹中尉))
  • ((Yes, Lieutenant.::
    是的，中尉。))

lightly

/ˈlaɪt.li//ˈlaɪt.li/
adverb
B1
轻轻地；稍稍地[英]^(gently)
  • ((She patted him lightly on the shoulder.::
    她轻轻地拍了拍他的肩膀。))
  • He touched me lightly on the cheek.
  • Dab the paint on lightly.
C1
稍微（烹调）一下;嫩（炒）地[英]^(If food is lightly cooked, it is cooked for only a short time.)
  • ((lightly cooked vegetables::
    烧得很嫩的蔬菜))
  • I like eggs lightly cooked so that the yolk is still runny.
轻松地，随便地;不严肃地[英]^(If you say something lightly, you are not serious when you say it.)
  • (("Anyway, it won't affect me because I'm leaving," she said lightly.::
    “不管怎么说，这对我都没什么影响，因为我就要走了，”她很轻松地说。))

not do something lightly

/ˈlaɪt.li//ˈlaɪt.li/
adverb
C2
高级部长提出这样的指控不可等闲视之。[英]^(If something is not said or treated lightly, it is said or treated in a serious way, after great thought)
  • ((Accusations like these from a top minister are not made lightly.::
    高级部长提出这样的指控不可等闲视之。))

like

/laɪk//laɪk/
verb [T]
A1
喜欢，喜爱[英]^(to enjoy or approve of something or someone)
  • ((I like your new haircut.::
    我喜欢你的新发型。))
  • ((Do you like fish?::
    你爱吃鱼吗？))
  • ((I like it when a book is so good that you can't put it down.::
    我喜欢那种碰上好书时手不释卷的感觉。))
  • ((I quite like wine but I could live without it.::
    我很喜欢喝酒，但没有酒我还是可以忍受的。))
  • ((He's very well-liked (= popular) at work.::
    他在单位里人缘相当好。))
  • ((I like the way he just assumes we'll listen to him when he doesn't take in a word anyone else says! (= I don't like it and it annoys me.)::
    他谁的话都听不进去，却以为我们大家都会听他的，对此我非常反感。))
  • ((I don't like upsetting people.::
    我不喜欢搞得别人心烦意乱。))
  • ((He likes to spend his evenings in front of the television.::
    他喜欢晚上看电视消磨时间。))
  • ((He likes his steak well-done.::
    他喜欢吃熟透的牛排。))
（在社交媒体上）点赞[英]^(to show that you think something is good on a social networking website by clicking on a symbol or the word 'like')
  • ((Like us on Facebook!::
    到脸书上为我们点赞吧！))
  • ((More than 200 people liked my post.::
    超过200人为我的文章点赞了。))
A1
（用于请求）想要，希望得到[英]^(used in requests)
  • ((I'd like one of the round loaves, please.::
    请给我拿一块圆面包。))
  • ((I'd like to book a seat for tonight's performance.::
    我想预订一个今晚演出的座位。))
  • ((I'd like you to send this for me, please.::
    请你帮我把这个寄出。))
  • ((I would like the whole lot finished by the weekend.::
    我希望这批活儿能在周末前做完。))
preposition, conjunction
A2
像；与…相似，与…近似[英]^(similar to; in the same way or manner as)
  • ((He looks like his brother.::
    他长得像他哥哥。))
  • ((She's very much like her mother (= she is similar in appearance or character).::
    她和她母亲非常像。))
  • ((Is Japanese food like Chinese?::
    日本料理和中餐相似吗？))
  • ((I've got a sweater just like that.::
    我有一件和那件一模一样的毛衣。))
  • ((Her hair was so soft it was like silk.::
    她的头发如丝绸般柔顺。))
  • ((You're acting like a complete idiot!::
    你的举动像个十足的白痴！))
  • ((She sings like an angel!::
    她的歌声如天使一般！))
  • ((Like I said (= as I have already said), I don't wear perfume.::
    我说过了，我不用香水。))
  • ((Like most people (= as most people would), I'd prefer to have enough money not to work.::
    和大多数人一样，我喜欢能有足够的钱而不必去工作。))
  • ((It feels/seems like (= it seems to me) ages since we last spoke.::
    我们好像很久没有说过话了。))
  • ((There's nothing like a good cup of coffee (= it's better than anything)!::
    任何东西都比不了一杯好咖啡！))
B1
好像，仿佛，似乎[英]^(in a way that suggests)
  • ((It looks like I'm going to be in the office until late tonight.::
    看起来我得到深夜才能离开办公室了。))
  • ((It looks like rain (= I think it is going to rain).::
    我看天要下雨了。))
  • ((It sounds to me like you ought to change jobs.::
    听起来你似乎应该换个工作。))
  • ((You look like you've just got out of bed!::
    你看起来好像刚刚起床！))
  • ((She acts like she's stupid!::
    她似乎总干傻事！))
preposition
B2
为…所特有的，符合…特点的[英]^(typical or characteristic of)
  • ((That's just like Maisie to turn up half an hour late to her own party!::
    梅茜就是这样的人，为她办聚会时她都要拖后半小时才露面！))
  • ((It's not like you to be so quiet - are you all right, my love?::
    你平时没这么安静呀——亲爱的，你没事吧？))
B1
例如，诸如[英]^(such as)
  • ((She looks best in bright, vibrant colours, like red and pink.::
    她穿鲜亮颜色的衣服最漂亮，如红色和粉色。))
adverb
（用于引出自己对已发生事件的感觉或想法）[英]^(used before you describe how you were feeling or what you said when something happened to you)
  • ((Then I saw how late it was and I'm like, so upset.::
    然后我才明白已经很晚了，因此感觉特别沮丧。))
  • ((He started shouting at me and I'm like, "What's your problem? I'm on your side!"::
    他开始朝我大喊大叫起来，于是我就问他：“你怎么回事？我是站在你这边的！”))
（用于对话中表示停顿或强调形容词）[英]^(used in conversation as a pause or to emphasize an adjective)
  • ((He's, like, really friendly - someone you can talk to.::
    他呀，真的非常友善——就是那种可以倾心交谈的人。))
  • ((If there's nothing you can do to change the situation, it's like - why bother?::
    如果你无法改变这种局面，那么干吗去劳这个神呢？))
noun [C]
（在社交媒体上）点赞[英]^((on a page on a social networking website) an act of showing that you think something is good by clicking a button)
  • ((My new profile picture got 100 likes.::
    我的新头像图片得到了100个赞。))

would like

/laɪk//laɪk/
verb [T]
(or formal should like...)
A1
想，想要，希望[英]^(used to say politely that you want something)
  • ((I think I'd like the soup for my starter.::
    我想要一份汤做头盘。))
  • ((I'd like to go to Moscow.::
    我想去莫斯科。))
  • ((I would like to say a big thank you to everyone who's helped to make our wedding such a special occasion!::
    我想对参与筹备我们婚礼的每一个人表示由衷的感谢，正是你们让这个婚礼如此与众不同！))

the like of someone/something; someone's/something's like

/laɪk//laɪk/
noun
(also the likes of someone/something)
…之类[英]^(a person, thing, or group similar in character or quality to the one mentioned)
  • ((Boxing hasn't seen the likes of Muhammad Ali since he retired.::
    穆罕默德·阿里退役后，拳击运动就再也没有他那样的选手了。))
  • ((He was a very great actor - we won't see his like again.::
    他是个非常了不起的演员——没有人能达到他那样的水平。))
  • ((He described a superlative meal, the like of which he'd never eaten before.::
    他说那顿饭特别美味，他从未吃过如此好吃的饭。))
  • ((They're competing with the likes of Microsoft.::
    他们在跟微软这样的公司竞争。))

and such like

/laɪk//laɪk/
noun
(also and the like)
等等，之类[英]^(and similar things)
  • ((There's a big sports hall for tennis and badminton and such like.::
    那里有一个可供网球、羽毛球等比赛用的大型体育馆。))

likes

/laɪk//laɪk/
noun [plural]
B2
喜好，爱好，最爱[英]^(the things that someone enjoys)
  • ((The star lists his likes as "my new Porsche, my girlfriend, and staying up all night."::
    这个流行歌星说他的最爱是“我的保时捷新车、女友和彻夜狂欢”。))
  • ((They can't expect me to accommodate all their silly little likes and dislikes.::
    他们别指望我能容忍他们所有那些愚蠢可笑、无足轻重的个人好恶。))

not for the likes of someone

/laɪk//laɪk/
noun
(also like)
不是为…之类的人准备的[英]^(not for the type of people mentioned)
  • ((First-class travel is for rich people - it's not for the likes of us.::
    头等舱是供上层人士使用的——不是给我们这样的人准备的。))

be like to do something

/laɪk//laɪk/
adjective
可能会做[英]^(to be likely to do something)

-like

/ -laɪk// -laɪk/
suffix
像…的，如…的[英]^(like the thing mentioned)
  • ((The paper criticized what it described as the animal-like behaviour of the fans.::
    该报批评了球迷们的表现，称之为野蛮行径。))
  • ((There was a large, ball-like structure on top of the building.::
    大楼的顶部有一个球型构造物。))
  • ((childlike trust::
    像孩子一样天真地信赖某人))
  • ((a cabbage-like vegetable::
    一种像卷心菜一样的蔬菜))

lime

/laɪm//laɪm/
noun
[C or U]
酸橙;酸橙树[英]^(a round fruit containing a lot of juice that is sour like a lemon but smaller and green, or the small tree on which this fruit grows)
[C]
(also lime tree); (US usually linden)
欧椴树[英]^(a large tree with leaves shaped like a heart and pale yellow flowers)
[U]
(also quicklime)
石灰[英]^(a white substance that is used especially to spread on the land to improve the quality of earth so that crops grow better)
[U]
(also limescale, scale)
水垢[英]^(white material that collects inside water pipes, kettles, etc. in areas where the water is hard (= contains a lot of natural chemicals))
verb [T]
撒石灰于[英]^(to spread the substance lime on a piece of land)

US

    她为自己拥有古老的皇室血统倍感自豪。))

loathe

/ləʊð//loʊð/
verb [T]
C2
恨，憎恨;厌恶[英]^(to hate someone or something)
  • ((From an early age the brothers have loathed each other.::
    自小时候起，兄弟俩就一直相互厌恶。))
  • (("Do you like fish?" "No, I loathe it."::
    “你喜欢鱼吗？”“不，我讨厌鱼。”))
  • ((I loathe doing housework.::
    我讨厌做家务。))

  • ((The locus of decision-making is sometimes far from the government's offices.::
    决策的地点有时根本就不在政府的办公室。))

noun [C]

阁楼，顶楼[英]^(a space at the top of a building under the roof used for storing things and usually entered by a ladder, or sometimes made into a room for living in)

    该公司专门从事阁楼改造。))

noun [plural]

  • ((We need to look at the logistics of the whole aid operation.::
    我们需要审视整个援助行动的后勤保障工作。))

lone

/ləʊn//loʊn/
adjective [before noun]

  • ((a lone survivor::
    唯一的幸存者))
  • ((He was a lone voice (= the only person) arguing against a reduction in payments.::
    他是唯一反对减薪的人。))

adjective [before noun]
